body.p:
First of all I have to crave
your pardon for addressing myself to you in the vernacul-
ar, & not in the language you prefer to correspond in
with your pupil. The arrival of the last issue of the
Israelite put me out of the humor of writing Hebrew.
Hebrew, the language of Truth, is the language of the Is-
raelites & before me lies a paper [Hebrew], replete
with bare-faced falsehoods!--

By this time you have doubtlessly seen the paper in
question—did you read my article on "Intermarriages" & the
"Editorial Postscript" therein contained? I do not ask
this question out of impure motives: out of the desire to
know whether my kind teacher has honored me by perusing
my crude thoughts; but because I am anxious to know
[Hebrew]? &therefore I propound the above
question. [Hebrew]

[Hebrew]
this is not the question. But do you find
my humble effort faithfully representing the views of
the opponents of the amalgamation schemers?

That I have succeeded to[?] in upsetting Wise's theories
[Hebrew], I infer from the fact that the Wise man
has nothing to say in reply to my arguments ([Hebrew])
except that 'none of his statements is attacked by me'--
& this is a [Hebrew], English:a black lie!__Who said,
"You see that ^ the reason of this prohibition [of intermarriage][previous brackets inserted by author] is not] none
of race, color or any other corporal accident"? Not Hirsch,
not Stern, but Dr. Wise; & at the close of Part 1 of my
paper I prove that race had as much to do with the
prohibition as religion.--Who asserted that 'the Rabbis
adopted the minority opinion of R. Simeon[?], & not that of
the majority opposed to him'? Dr. Wise! And in part 2
of my paper I show that R.S. was not the author of that
opinion, but that he simply delivered it as a Halakha adopted

[Hebrew] long before his birth.__ Who wrote,
in connection with the condition of the offspring of illegal marria-
ges: "R.S. Z. [Y.] is left there in the minority, & strange to
say, has been made law by the code. We know not on what
principle"? The paper itself answers: "Ed. Israelite"; & in
part 3 of my paper I controvert this assertion, & in part
4 expound the principle on which the law is based! In-
deed, my whole essay is directed against Dr Wise whose
every assertion is demonstrated to be the creation of
his brains & [Hebrew], not even [Hebrew]__ Dr's
Hirsch & Stern being brought in just for company's
sake__& yet he says in his "Postscript," that 'none of
his points is attacked in the above essay!!__ Moreover,
[Hebrew], he reiterates in the "Postscript" the very
ideas I refute in my paper, ] & styles these "facts," as
if there were no doubt as to their being facts!__Un-
forunately, & I say this with a sense of sorrow for the Re-
ligion I have been taught to revere, I know that only [Hebrew]
will read my article, while all will read
Wise's postscript & ninety nine out of every 100 will take
his words for it & consider it as [Hebrew].--

Now, what is to be done to counteract the effects of
the idolatrous worship paid the Wise man of the West?
My voice is too weak to silence him. Besides, his false-
hoods are more powerful than my truths. [Hebrew]
[Hebrew] --& Wise [Hebrew]! And yet, is
this [Hebrew]? The pacific policy of the conscientious
Rabbis in this country has raised that man to the
dignified position he occupies & rendered him second only
to the keeper of St.Peters's key to heaven, & the continuance
of that policy is paramount to wearing around his
brazen brow a crown of laurels every fiber of which
is a thorn in the side of Judaism. Can the [Hebrew]
[Hebrew] afford to maintain silence?-- Pardon me for speak-
ing thus to you [Hebrew]! My heart actually
aches within me whenever I think of the evil that man
has brought to Judaism, [Hebrew].
I am powerless & my pen is suffering with chronic impoten-
cy; your arm is strong, your pen prolific, your name
revered, your word respected: I candidly think that you
are the one [Hebrew].--
Yesterday I received from Berlin a copy of Frankel's

[Hebrew], & am therefore able to return to you the copy you
kindly lent me some seven months ago. I forward it
to your address by to-day's mail, registered, & hereby
tender you my heartfelt thanks for the loan. I have
made frequent use of it, but hope that you will ^ find the
book in no worse condition for all that.__ The copy
I received will cost me some $4 50
100/ __ an enormous
price for such a work, but I must have it & pay
for it!

For the present I shall be a [Hebrew], i.e. I shall
not reply to Wise's postscript, but wait till I hear
from Hirsch & Stern & then shape my course.

With kindest regards & best wishes for yourself & your dear children, in which my wife cordially joins,
I have the honor to subscribe myself,
